name: Chocolate Peanut Butter Muffins
name_origin: This is a Modern Hebrew descriptive name for a distinctly Western (American) dish. The word 'Muffins' (מאפינס) is a direct loanword from English into Modern Hebrew. 'Shokolad' (שוקולד) is a loanword ultimately derived from Nahuatl 'xocolātl'. 'Chemat Botnim' (חמאת בוטנים) is the Modern Hebrew calque for 'Peanut Butter'. The word 'Botnim' (בוטנים) appears in the Bible (Genesis 43:11) referring to pistachios or terebinth nuts, but was repurposed in Modern Hebrew to mean 'peanuts' (which are New World in origin). In Tunisian Arabic (Derja), peanuts are called 'Kakawiya' (from the Spanish 'cacahuete'), but this dish does not carry a Judeo-Arabic name because it is a modern addition to the repertoire, likely introduced via Israeli or French influence after emigration from Djerba.
description: Rich and moist muffins combining the classic duo of chocolate and peanut butter. A simple batter that comes together quickly, perfect for a sweet breakfast or snack.
cultural_context: While not a traditional North African dish, this recipe represents the modern baking repertoire found in contemporary Jewish kitchens. The option to use water instead of milk makes these pareve, suitable for dessert after a meat meal.
vegan_adaptation_notes: Replace the egg with a flax egg or applesauce to make vegan.

steps.instruction: Preheat the oven to 180°C (350°F). Grease a standard 12-cup muffin tin.
In a large bowl, mix the dry ingredients: flour, chocolate chips, sugar, baking powder, and salt.
In a separate small bowl, whisk together the wet ingredients: milk (or water), peanut butter, oil, and the egg.
Pour the wet mixture into the bowl of dry ingredients. Mix gently until just blended; do not overmix.
Fill each muffin cup about 3/4 full with batter.
Bake for 20 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.

name_etymology.notes: This is not a traditional Djerban or Maghrebi dish. Traditional Tunisian Jewish baking relies on sponge cakes (Bouskoutou), semolina cakes (Harissa/Basbousa), or fried doughs (Yo-yos, Sfenj). The presence of peanut butter—a distinctly American ingredient—confirms this is a modern recipe adopted by the community in the diaspora (Israel or France).

alternative_names.name: Muffins au chocolat et beurre de cacahuète
alternative_names.notes: Likely name used by Tunisian Jews living in France, where 'beurre de cacahuète' is the standard term.

alternative_names.name: Kakawiya
alternative_names.notes: The specific word for 'peanut' in Tunisian dialect, though not used in the title of this specific muffin dish.

similar_dishes.name: American Muffins
similar_dishes.similarity: The direct culinary ancestor of this dish.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Identical format; the Jewish version is Pareve (non-dairy) if served after meat meals, often substituting oil for butter.

similar_dishes.name: Bouskoutou / Boulou
similar_dishes.similarity: The traditional functional equivalent: a simple cake/biscuit eaten for breakfast or snack.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Bouskoutou is a sponge cake flavored with lemon/orange zest and vanilla, utilizing oil and eggs, without peanut butter or chocolate chips.

similar_dishes.name: Bjawia
similar_dishes.similarity: A sweet confection utilizing nuts, often including peanuts (kakawiya).
similar_dishes.key_difference: Bjawia is a dense confection of nuts and syrup, not a baked flour-based cake.

intro_paragraph: Muffins Shokolad ve'Chemat Botnim utilize the biblical word botnim, originally meaning pistachios, to describe peanuts in Modern Hebrew. While a departure from traditional North African cuisine, these rich American-style muffins represent the global influences in contemporary Jewish baking. Often prepared with water rather than milk, they offer a moist pareve treat suitable after a meat meal.
